Isn't it about 3 times as hard to get admitted to EECS as a freshman? Also, CS outnumber EECS as of recent, and CS is almost all of the recent growth in class size recently. So I think the current system is fair as it is. 

I say this as a recently declared (as in with the 3.3 cap) CS sophomore.

-------

A point I would like to make that I don't see being brought up is the fact that EECS majors also have the requirements of Physics 7A/B and Math 53, which are typically taken within their first three semesters. These courses are no cake walk, and take a non-trivial amount of time away from being able to focus on the 61 series. 

The fact that EECS isn't just CS, but EE as well also makes the GPA cutoff for 3 CS classes impractical for those EECS majors who care more about EE. It wouldn't make sense for L&S to add 16a/b to the gpa cutoff would it now?

I think everyone agrees that having a GPA cutoff for CS majors is not optimal. Maybe it would be a better use of time to think about different solutions instead of trying to force nonoptimal  solutions on everyone?

children.subject: +1 I think that the lack of a GPA cutoff for EECS majors hurts the prestige of the degree

The number of people admitted to EECS is already capped (to a certain extent) during the process of admitting new students. The number of people who can declare CS through LSCS is not capped; this is the reason for a GPA cutoff, as there are not (unfortunately) currently sufficient resources for everyone who wants to take CS classes.

I think the salient question here is why there are two avenues for people to enter into CS here at Berkeley - one through the admissions office, and one through an somewhat meritocratic process (GPA cutoff). I've met some EECS majors who themselves say they would never make the 3.3 cutoff, but that's not necessarily a bad thing since the admissions office is presumably better equipped to deal with diversity (tm) issues.

Also side question, if there was a 3.3 GPA cutoff, where would the EECS people who fail the cutoff go?

What about the EE-focused people who don't care for the CS lower divs? Also the EE upper divs are much less highly impacted compared to the CS upper divs, so should they have a lower standard? And where does that leave those interested in the intersection of EE and CS?

children.subject: [and I say this as an L&S CS major]

+1 Literally know 5 people who applied as other L&S majors with the intention of always being CS. Frankly speaking, while I wish there was no need for a GPA cap (I'd even prefer there to be a different system if we did have to prevent people from studying CS. I don't believe its the best way to find people who are best suited for the major/have the most passion for it) there is, and COE majors are annoyingly difficult to get into as is. In essence, the GPA cutoff is enforced off of your high school GPA (sorta. definitely wishy washy logic on that last part)

When you apply to EECS, you're applying to get the major on the spot when you're admitted. The reason L&S CS has a GPA cap is because anyone in college that is undecided/in the general college can work to get the major, and there are far more of those students. EECS students are filtered before they are admitted, whereas L&S CS students are filtered after being admitted. It makes no sense to impose a GPA cap on EECS.

It's tempting to impose one's pain onto others. That doesn't mean it is justified. We should have sympathy on our fellow EECS students and try to make things easier - not harder - on them than they are on us. Let's not forget if it wasn't for eecs, Berkeley wouldn't even crack the top 20 in rankings. Thank them for the top professors and research funding.

history.content: As an L&S CS major I think that given how impacted our classes are even at the upper division level, it would be only just to apply the same filter used against L&S students to EECS students both from a fairness perspective and also so that our classes will not be as impacted as they currently are. What are people's thoughts about this?
